title: LeBron James Says Tweet Supporting Hong Kong Protests Was 'Misinformed'
summary: In his first comments about the league's standoff with China, the NBA superstar criticized Rockets general manager Daryl Morey, saying 'I believe he wasn't educated on the situation'. Los Angeles Lakers superstar LeBron James criticized Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey for the tweet that set off a crisis between the NBA and China, saying that Morey's support for antigovernment protesters in Hong Kong was "misinformed or not really educated on the situation."

title: Former Russia Adviser Testifies She Was Alarmed About Ukraine Pressure
summary: Fiona Hill's nine-hour testimony comes as Democrats examine Trump's effort to get Kyiv to investigate Bidens. title: This App Helps You Learn About China, While China Learns All About You

title: The Warren-Zuckerberg Clash
summary: The candidate wants to join with Big Tech to suppress her opposition.. Silicon Valley companies excel at many things, but there's little evidence their expertise extends to designing ingenious new systems for controlling political speech. That's why Facebook was wise to confirm last month that it won't try to police the ads of politicians for false statements as it does ordinary ads. Facebook's vice president of global affairs and communications Nick Clegg wrote that the company does not believe its role is to "prevent a politician's speech from reaching its audience and being subject to public debate and scrutiny."

title: Puerto Rico at the Supreme Court
summary: Congress has the power to manage territories as it wants.. Amid a spiraling economic crisis in Puerto Rico, Congress established a control board to impose outside discipline. The Supreme Court on Tuesday will consider the board's constitutionality in a case that ostensibly pits Congress's plenary authority over U.S. territories against the Appointments Clause. Yet there is no real constitutional conflict between the two.

summary: Artificial intelligence promises all sorts of advances for medicine. And all sorts of concerns.. Could a machine-learning algorithm diagnose your next illness?

title: China's Techno-Kleptomania
summary: Beijing's schemes imperil American companies and national security. It'll take a huge effort to stop them.. The news that the U.S. has arrested Peng Xuehua of Hayward, Calif., for allegedly funneling classified American secrets to China's Ministry of State Security can't be dismissed as an isolated incident. Beijing seems to be digging for technological secrets across the U.S. Director Christopher Wray said in July that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has 1,000 active investigations into attempted intellectual property theft in America, mostly involving China.

title: Turkey Is Stepping Up Where Others Fail to Act
summary: Syria's refugee flows, violence and instability have pushed us to the limit of our tolerance.. Since the Syrian civil war began in 2011, no country has felt the pain of the ensuing humanitarian crisis more severely than Turkey. We took in 3.6 million Syrian refugees-more than any other country-and spent $40 billion to offer them education, health care and housing. Our culture of hospitality compelled us to shoulder the burden of hosting millions of war victims with very little help from the international community.

title: Nobel Laureates Aim Too Low on Global Poverty
summary: Immigration and growth would help more than addressing the winners' 'manageable questions.'. The award reveals a deepening fault line among economists about how best to fight poverty.

title: 'Return to the Reich' Review: Refugee Redux
summary: The true story of a Jewish boy from Freiburg who escaped Nazi Germany only to return as an American commando on a secret mission.. It was with noble purpose that Eric Lichtblau came to write "Return to the Reich." He wanted to celebrate the anonymous, unsung heroes of World War II and sought the advice of Eli Rosenbaum, a former director of the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations. Mr. Rosenbaum, a long-time Nazi hunter, suggested the author look up Freddy Mayer, who led one of the war's most successful spy efforts.

title: Mike Pompeo's Predicament
summary: The Syria withdrawal worried allies, divided the GOP, and made his job a lot harder.. Foreign leaders have found much to dislike in President Trump's policy-the aggressive stance on trade, the chaotic policy process, the disregard for convention and past agreements. Yet they've seemed willing to work with the administration anyway. However much it pained them, they appeared to believe that Mr. Trump had a strong enough political coalition behind his foreign-policy program that, on the whole, it was better to deal pragmatically with the administration than to try to wait out his presidency.

title: 'Fuzzy-Profound' Words Cause Mental Rot
summary: They make it seem like deep thinking is going on, but it isn't.. What are "qualia"? I stumbled on the word recently in the Times Literary Supplement, where a review of novels by Neal Stephenson and Don DeLillo observed that both authors "are much concerned with qualia." I looked up "quale," the singular, in the Oxford English Dictionary, which defines it as "the property or quality of a thing; Philosophy a quality or property as perceived or experienced by a person; (also) a thing having certain qualities."

title: Our Kurdish Allies Shamefully Abandoned
summary: This seems to be the result of a telephone call with the Turkish dictator, executed without comprehensive staff consultation and consideration.. Regarding your editorial "With Friends Like the U.S." (Oct. 8): A great nation doesn't betray its friends. When one group is so mistreated, others take notice. Among friends, trust implodes; among foes, expectations explode. While such past betrayals have been bipartisan, this administration has been particularly reckless in raising the dangers. It failed to respond to Iran's shooting down of an American drone flying over international waters and to the Pearl Harbor-like attack on Saudi Arabian oil facilities. Sanctions were an insufficient response; bullets would have been better.

title: Louisiana: Focus on Health, Not Abortion
summary: Louisiana could better invest its resources to actually improve the health and safety of its residents rather than wasting time, energy and dollars to promote a law which has no proven benefit.. Regarding your editorial "A Judicial Abortion Test" (Oct. 7): The Louisiana law requiring doctors who perform abortions to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital was ostensibly passed to ensure the health and safety of women in Louisiana, but in reality its intent is to severely limit or even eliminate access to abortion services in the state. In this context, it is useful to look at the current health status of the people in Louisiana. Life expectancy at 75.6 years is three years shorter than the national average. The neonatal mortality rate is 7.5/1,000 live births compared with the national rate of 5.8/1000 live births. The state ranks fifth in cancer and heart-disease death rates and has the second highest rates for preterm births and low- birthrate infants. The adult obesity rate is 36.8% compared with the U.S. average of 29.9%, and the adult smoking rate is 23.1% compared with the U.S. average of 14%.

title: Congress Should Balk; It's Not the Universal Umpire
summary: More and more Americans seem to accept as a legitimate role of government the coercion of private citizens in areas having nothing whatsoever to do with the roles of government spelled out in our Constitution.. Regarding Andy Smith's Oct. 5 letter responding to Joanna Cohen's "Put the Playoffs Back in Waking Hours" (op-ed, Oct. 1): I am as nostalgic as anyone about the good old days of kids sneaking their transistor radios into school to hear an afternoon World Series game on a free broadcast. But I nearly went into shock reading Mr. Smith's letter suggesting that Congress should dictate schedules and outlets for baseball broadcasts.

title: Those Supercenters May Not Be That Super
summary: "Supercenters" are staffed by midlevel professionals with a master's degree, not physicians. This model works well for the healthy but may pose a serious threat to the yet undiagnosed kidney failure, cardiac or cancer patient.. "A Supercenter for Medicine" isn't the answer as Charles Silver and David A. Hyman suggest (op-ed, Oct. 4). Physician visits account for only 20% of total health-care spending in the U.S. Is it wise to run them out of business? It is important to point out that these "supercenters" are staffed by midlevel professionals with a master's degree, not physicians. Some may say this is fine and they will see a doctor for the "serious" issues. The problem is many serious issues present as common colds, lumps and bumps, etc. This model works well for the healthy but may pose a serious threat to the yet undiagnosed kidney failure, cardiac or cancer patient. We'd do well to remember that we are not paying doctors $100 for 10 minutes of their time. We are paying them for the 8-12 years of medical and post-medical-school training that allows them to diagnose and treat us in 10 minutes. Buyer beware. You get what you pay for.

title: Legal, Regulated Pot Is the Answer to Vaping Deaths
summary: The correct way to fix the problem of poisonous THC vaping is to legalize and regulate it.. I'm sorry to say that Dr. Scott Gottlieb has it completely backward ("Pot Legalization Makes Vaping Deadly," op-ed, Oct. 11). The correct way to fix the problem of poisonous THC vaping is to legalize and regulate it. His article goes on and on citing the consequences of not doing so. I'm sure he doesn't realize it, but he is simply underscoring the reasons why some states have stepped forward to protect their citizens by bringing marijuana into the legal and regulated arena.

summary: Employers are becoming more flexible about time spent away from work, thanks to a tight labor market and a greater cultural shift. How long can you step out of the workforce without sinking your career? The answer may surprise you.

title: Drawn by the Salary, Women Flock to Trucking
summary: Resume Subscription. Last year, Rebekah Koon left her job as an assistant manager of a gas station in Fort Bragg, N.C., to train as a truck driver, inspired by watching her uncle hit the road as a long-haul trucker when she was growing up.

title: Deere Ramps Up Leases as Sales Slow
summary: Renting equipment to stressed U.S. farmers boosts sales but is more complex than lending customers money for purchases. Deere & Co. is spending billions of dollars annually to buy its own equipment for a leasing program, which lifts sales of new farm tractors and construction machinery but adds financial complexity and weighs on the used-equipment market.

title: Silicon Valley Takes On Amazon's Cashierless 'Go' Stores
summary: Zippin and Standard Cognition are two of the startups pitching their systems and apps as nonthreatening alternatives to Amazon's cashier-free tech. SAN FRANCISCO- Amazon.com Inc. recently opened its fourth cashierless convenience store here, all located within a few blocks of each other. Nearby, two startups are each demonstrating their own technology that they envision powering cashier-free stores across America.

title: Congress Probes Bot Messages About E-Cigarettes
summary: House investigators ask five manufacturers of vaping products whether they used bots for marketing. WASHINGTON-A congressional committee and the Massachusetts attorney general are investigating whether millions of bot-generated social-media messages about e-cigarettes have been misleading consumers about safety and health issues.

title: Companies Say Costs of Complying With Goodwill Accounting Rules Outweigh Benefits
summary: New feedback could help FASB decide whether to change standards on assets tied to company acquisitions. Company executives who were recently asked to weigh in on existing rules governing how companies account for goodwill in their financial statements say the standards have saddled them with unnecessary costs and are too subjective.

title: China's U.S. Exports Tumble as Tariffs Bite
summary: Shipments to the U.S. slumped nearly 22% in September, while overall exports were down 3.2%. BEIJING-China's exports to the U.S. shrank by more than one-fifth last month, hit by heavier tariffs, underscoring the urgency for Beijing to resolve trade friction with Washington.

title: Ecuador Scraps Measure to Slash Fuel Subsidies After Deadly Protests
summary: The government plans to form a joint commission with the indigenous groups that opposed the measure to discuss a planned economic overhaul.. QUITO, Ecuador-President Lenín Moreno agreed to scrap a decree to eliminate fuel subsidies and indigenous groups called an end to strikes and protests after almost two weeks of street clashes triggered by Ecuador's austerity measures.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
